Interesting note I haven't seen mentioned---

First, Desmond's presence on the Oceanic flight in the AU (alternate universe for the newbs) is extremely telling. I think what we are going to see is more "fractals" --incidences, coincidences and intersections-- between our main characters in the "2nd Cat" universe. Desmond's appearance/disappearance might cause inconsistencies in the new world that bring the characters closer together.

Second, when Jack has a moment of recognition after seeing Desmond, I believe he is remembering (subconsciously) when they met at the stadium while running laps. Desmond was about to take off on his around-the-world boat tour, and Jack was running laps, dealing with his divorce. See? All full circle.
Also, Desmond was Daniel Farraday's "constant" in the time flux, and Daniel was Desmond's. Perhaps Desmond is also a constant for Jack, and vice-versa, since they both met before the original Oceanic flight crashed.

Just a thought. There is SO MUCH information to think about and so many diverse, disparate timelines to consider that it's hard to get a grip on all the ins and outs of the Island. But I love it! And I came late to the game-- I was a major hater on Lost for many, many years.

The oxygen wasting criminals are not buying their guns or ammo through Oakland's non existent gun stores now.  So what makes Larry Reid think these new regulations will have any effect on their supply chains?   What a pointless exercise!

So, let's see, who's the pointy headed idiot here? There are no gun shops in Oakland, so they want to pass additional laws regulating them. Never mind that all of the behaviors this is supposedly meant to stop are already illegal. Never mind that every one of these laws is itself illegal, violating California state preemption laws, the California state constitution, and/or the US constitution (and I don't mean the second amendment, but the 4th, 5th, and 14th amendments). So when they get sued, this city that's already nearly broke will waste hundreds of thousands of dollars to defend against lawsuits that it's basically already lost, because these same laws have already been struck down in other California cities in court, for the reasons I cited. LCAV has tried this in several cities already, and they've lost every time. Most are smart enough to send them packing. But apparently the Oakland city council is made up of people too stupid to even read a newspaper and see that LCAV's pathetic BS has already been tested and failed, publicly, more than once. Or maybe they just need to hide some more money they've syphoned off and figure a guaranteed-loser legal battle is a good way to hide their pilfering.

As a would-be Twitter novelist, I must take exception to Mr. Packer's negative portrayal of Twitter. Since May, 2009 I have published installments of my comic-murder mystery "Executive Severance" twice a day, 140 characters (or less!) at a time. (Those interested can follow me on Twitter at RKBs_Twitstery or read my entire work to date at www.textnovel.com.) !!! I've just realized that in this comment I've far exceeded my normal 140 character limit! What a release! What a marvelous feeling of freedom! I never realized how satisfying it could be to ramble on and on and never get to the point! I now understand how Twitter has stifled my creativity and shackled my authorial output. I'm sure the late, great J.D. Salinger felt the same way! Thank you, all, for showing me the light and releasing me from my Twitter bondage!
BTW, would anyone like to purchase a bound copy of my book, "Executive Severance" at $22.95? It is still a work in progress, but I expect to complete it soon and could send off your personal, autographed first edition copy. Please help support a struggling artist with your contributions. Thank you.

My first take on the iPad, was that I was going to get one as soon as it becomes available, but as more, and more, of it's deficiencies have been revealed, I have begun to re-think my enthusiasm. I think many people will wait for the next generation of the iPad before taking the plunge. I already have an Apple iMac and have had several generations of the iPhone and iPod, and I love Apple products, but I think just maybe the "i" is getting a bit old. It's not that Apple has done wrong by the iPad, I just don't think it has really done right by it. What has worked for Apple in the past, announcing a new product, and then letting people wait, and anticipate, may back-fire this time, it may allow enough time for people to stop and think, "I can just wait this generation of the iPad out, until it becomes really clear just what Apple is offering in the iPad". I completely believe the the e-book is here to stay, and have two Kindles, and love them, and believe that the future of the e-book is in color, and internet access, and video etc, but, I think, many people will just wait this one out. The Kindle won't be immediately threatened, in fact, I think there will be kind of a "reverse chic" about owning a Kindle, with it's rather subdued, if not down right plain Jane look.

Amazon is straying quite a ways from it's core competency. Do they really believe that they can hold their own against the best hardware company in the world? As one of the eBook reader pioneers they had some success with Kindle but really take a look at the thing, then take a look at an Apple mobile device. Come on, let's stop kidding ourselves.

If I were an Amazon stockholder, I would be calling, writing, e-mailing Jeff Bezos to ask him to stop this nonsense. It's a pipe dream that can only end in the destruction of shareholder value.

This service is for businesses. It clearly says patients are in the future. The developers know that they need to be careful when having physicians communicate directly with physicians. It's a great way for industry (media, healthcare firms, financial firms) to get quick input from lots of physicians. The price is for the speed of response. Consumer use will definitely need to be handled differently and my guess is the developer knows this, otherwise it would be available now.

One of the important issues to decide is whether there is liability when someone's computer is infected by a virus or used as a remotely-controlled "zombie".

It is unlikely that a criminal would use their own (licensed) machine. Instead, hackers take over the undersecured computers of less savvy. A license may tell you who left their computer unprotected, but it will still be difficult to trace the attack back to the origin because the attacker will have likely used several layers of unsecured proxies.

To continue the car anology, are you liable if someone steals your car and uses it to do something bad? The fact that you and the car both have licenses doesn't really stop this sort of crime, it mearly helps identify whose vehicle was used.

For more on the security aspects this, read Bruce Schneier:
http://www.schneier.com...

Ideally, there would be no wars and no need for Presidential condolence letters. That not being the case, ALL families of deceased service members deserve such a letter. Families whose loved one kill themselves need it even MORE. For a President to ever deny such a simple show of compassion is not only heartless and indefensible, but unconscionable - it doubly punishes the family through no fault of their own.

No matter how one may try to justify or rationalize it, WAR is not a normal state of man (that’s why men must be trained to it) - it is an aberration of the human condition on countless levels.

War is an assault on the soul.

Is it any wonder then, that so many gentle souls, not ‘hardened’ (or numb?) to the rigors and atrocities of war as some others might be by different constitutions, reject the horrors and duties as untenable? I cannot even imagine the profound and desolate loneliness of a young soldier serving his country, far from home, abandoned by those he trusted most to help him.

White House, skip the ridiculous “review”. Mr. President, write letters from the heart to each and every family - then send up a silent prayer thanking God your children still live.

Eileen, we on At War would be interested in hearing about your experiences in Afghanistan. If you want to, drop me an email on atwar@nytimes.com

Wes,

I'm also a college student, and on campus, I'm also THAT kid. The one that spent winter break in Afghanistan, and whose conversations inevitably become peppered with references to a world that is completely foreign to most of my peers. The one who isn't paying attention to the debates on health care reform or the results of our state's latest senatorial race results, but who does care immensely about the state of ANP training.

It's nice to know that despite how crazy it seems to the folks up here for an undergrad to be in Iraq or Afghanistan, I'm not the only one.

I also think that part of our job is to make people more aware of what's going on. Iraq and Afghanistan might seem like terribly vague, distant concepts that have no relevance to the realities of college life, but just the fact that you're there, among them, and that you've also been in Iraq and Afghanistan brings the wars closer. Even if the only conversations re: OIF or OEF are with you, hey, that's at least a step, right?
